BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Suggested further reading Paul Auster, The New York Trilogy; Roberto Bolano, 2666; Julio Cortazar, Hopscotch; Umberto Eco, The Prague Cemetery; Neal Stephenson, Cryptonomicon; Kurt Vonnegut, Slaughterhouse Five; David Foster Wallace, Infinite Jest.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Where there is light, there must be shadow, where there is shadow, there must be light. There is no shadow without light and no light without shadow….

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Knowledge and ability were tools, not things to show off.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: But in order to get into a top university, and pass the bar exam, I had to study like mad, just like Tengo and Aomame. I had no time to have fun like my classmates. I had to abstain from all worldly pleasures—not that I had much chance of obtaining them to begin with—and focus solely on my studies. I was always stuck between feelings of inferiority and superiority.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Karl Jung said this about ‘the Shadow’ in one of his books: ‘It is as evil as we are positive … the more desperately we try to be good and wonderful and perfect, the more the Shadow develops a definite will to be black and evil and destructive.… The fact is that if one tries beyond one’s capacity to be perfect, the Shadow descends to hell and becomes the devil. For it is just as sinful from the standpoint of nature and of truth to be above oneself as to be below oneself.’

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: The scene outside the window suggested that the world had settled in a place somewhere midway between “being miserable” and “lacking in joy,” and consisted of an infinite agglomeration of variously shaped microcosms.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: their lives have some meaning. Which is where religion comes from.”

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: “Most people are not looking for provable truths. As you said, truth is often accompanied by intense pain, and almost no one is looking for painful truths. What people need is beautiful, comforting stories that make them feel as

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Though she tried to forget it, the nothingness would visit her periodically—on a lonely rainy afternoon, or at dawn when she woke from a nightmare.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Aomame said, “It’s like the Tibetan Wheel of the Passions. As the wheel turns, the values and feelings on the outer rim rise and fall, shining or sinking into darkness. But true love stays fastened to the axle and doesn’t move.”

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: That’s what the world is, after all: an endless battle of contrasting memories.”

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Surely, if a person had to accept the time through which he had just passed uniformly in the given order, his nerves could not bear the strain. Such a life, Tengo felt, would be sheer torture.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Human beings are ultimately nothing but carriers—passageways—for genes.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: They ride us into the ground like racehorses from generation to generation. Genes don’t think about what constitutes good or evil. They don’t care whether we are happy or unhappy. We’re just a means to an end for them. The only thing they think about is what is most efficient for them.”

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: “But if you can love someone with your whole heart—even if he’s a terrible person and even if he doesn’t love you back—life is not a hell, at least, though it might be kind of dark.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: “If you can love someone with your whole heart, even one person, then there’s salvation in life. Even if you can’t get together with that person.”

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: “ ‘Every art and every inquiry, and similarly every action and pursuit, is thought to aim at some good; and for this reason the good has rightly been declared to be that at which all things aim.’ ”

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: people might be able to belong to something even as they maintain their autonomy.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: One aim of my field is to relativize the images possessed by individuals, discover in these images the factors universal to all human beings, and feed these universal truths back to those same individuals. As a result of this process,

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Aomame felt not the slightest regret at having caused male club members to feel anxious and annoyed and upset. Such unpleasant feelings were nothing compared with the pain experienced by a victim of forcible rape.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: a spectacle like that is going to make most men feel anxious and annoyed and upset.”

Content: The leaders use their power to crush people’s

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: natural desire to think for themselves. It’s foot-binding for the brain.”

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: What

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Takashima is doing, if you ask me, is making mindless robots. They take the circuits out of people’s brains that make it possible for them to think for themselves. Their

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: she felt only revulsion for any kind of religious fundamentalists. The very thought of such people’s intolerant worldview, their inflated sense of their own superiority, and their callous imposition of their own beliefs on others was enough to fill her with rage.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Subtraction was a far simpler process than addition, and it reduced the volume of his text by some thirty percent. It was a kind of mind game. He would set a certain time period for expanding the text as much as possible, then set a certain time period for reducing the text as much as possible.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Women have it much tougher than men. Have you ever had to climb down a steep stairway in high heels,

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: was the kind of smile he might have found way in the back of a normally unopened drawer.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: Seeing what’s under my skirt doesn’t let them really see me as a person.

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: “Right. And after you do something like that, the everyday look of things might seem to

BookAuthor: Haruki Murakami and Jay Rubin and and Philip Gabriel
Content: change a little. Things may look different to you than they did before. I’ve had that experience myself. But don’t let appearances fool you. There’s always only one reality.”
